Company: University of Illinois at Chicago Medical Center
Description: The University of Illinois paid the United States and the State of Illinois $2 million to settle a lawsuit filed in July that alleged the University's Medical Center at Chicago improperly diagnosed and hospitalized certain patients in the late 1990s to allow them to become eligible sooner for liver transplants.

The University of Illinois agreed to pay $2 million to settle a lawsuit alleging it falsely diagnosed patients to allow them to become eligible sooner for liver transplants, increasing the amount of Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement it recieved. The State of Illinois received $751,234, of which $250,4115 was paid to the whistleblower. The case was also reported by the Justice Department; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/il-university-of-illinois-at-chicago-medica

Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on October 15, 2020 in response to an open records request. The data is a spreadsheet version of the entries contained in the search engine at http://www.epa.state.il.us/cgi-bin/en/orders/orders.pl
Extracted from a download of the EPA's Enforcement and Compliance History Online (ECHO) ICIS FE&C file downloaded on 3/02/2022, available at http://echo.epa.gov/tools/data-downloads#downloads
